```{r reading in the data}

## Reading in baseline data

# Have to skp 3 rows and assign no names since the Qualtrics reads the data in super weird

zip2feat_data <- read_csv("zipcode2features_example_data")

# Now reading in only the first row and using the janitor package to make the non-named qualtrics variables more tidy

cg_baseline_names <- read_csv("college_goals_fall_2020_baseline_choice_text.csv") %>% 
  slice(1) %>% 
  names() %>% 
  make_clean_names()

# Assigning these values to names of the baseline data

names(cg_baseline) <- cg_baseline_names  

glimpse(cg_baseline)

## Reading in the follow-up data

cg_follow_up <- read_csv("college_goals_fall_2020_follow_up_choice_text.csv", skip = 3, col_names = F)

cg_follow_up_names <- read_csv("college_goals_fall_2020_follow_up_choice_text.csv") %>% 
  slice(1) %>% 
  names() %>% 
  make_clean_names()

names(cg_follow_up) <- cg_follow_up_names  

glimpse(cg_follow_up)

```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure, echo=FALSE}
plot(pressure)
```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.
